Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Commercialization Feasibility Research for a Rigid Support System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project reaches many different silos, including disaster relief, logistics, and personal protective equipment, through innovations in custom manufacturing and rapid prototyping. This I-Corps project is exploring the commercialization feasibility for a method to protect any amorphous shape with a rigid, adaptable fit system. There are many application areas where a method to form a rigid support system would be useful and transformative. For example, this method requires minimal, non-professional training and no water or external additives to catalyze the cure from liquid to solid. If results of this study suggest that this technology has merit as a medical device, it could transform the way patients are treated for broken bones, how victims are cared for in disaster relief areas, and how medical treatment is administered in the third world. Additionally, the current standard for protecting fragile objects during shipping is with polymer-reinforced paper, plastic peanuts, or sheets of air-puffed plastic. Objects of unidentifiable shapes could be more efficiently packed with this adaptable-fit technology.

This I-Corps project proposes to conduct commercialization feasibility research on a method for protecting any amorphous shape with a rigid, adaptable fit system. The proposed technology utilizes research in manufacturing techniques to develop a novel method for custom forming a rigid support structure around an amorphous shape. The method consists of a network of tubing that contains one or more liquids, such that an external stimulus may trigger the transformation of one or more of these liquids into solid form. The tubes connect in a lattice structure that allows them to expand and contract in order to fit to an amorphous shape. Exploring this new method of forming a rigid structure can advance the fields of custom manufacturing and rapid prototyping. The technology allows for rapid creation of a custom-fit part in the field, without any external tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this study was to determine the commercial feasibility of a rapidly adjustable, conforming waterproof structure. The result of hundreds of interviews with industry leaders across several disciplines was the expressed interest of such a technology to be used as a brace for addressing bone fractures and joint pain. Since, the form-factor of the technology has been adapted into a system for creating, applying, and removing a fracture orthotic. This particular system does not require electricity, heat, or water, therefore increasing its global usability.

 

After exploring the healthcare system for humans and animals, in the United States and abroad, the team settled on the optimal market opportunity in human orthopedics in the States. Market size and anatomical proportions played a key role in deciding which living beings to use. Per the Food and Drug Administration, the technology as a brace has the lowest government regulation in the United States when compared to other developed nations. What we have found, however, is that the United States insurance system is a major obstacle for innovators and physicians. Further studies will determine whether or not this prevents the team from commercializing first in the United States.

 

The team was intrigued to learn the driving force behind physicians was the monetary return on investment. In doctor offices today, no orthopedic disposable returned less than two-times the initial purchased price - returned either through insurance or patients paying out of pocket. Knowing that insurance would be a major hurdle for the small team, the group also investigated the potential interaction between the patient, money, and the product. The team learned more than 60% of end users said they would pay upwards of 50USD for a product with the benefits that we could provide, and the average price users would pay was between 182-200USD. These figures will be used to guide a pricing and manufacturing strategy.

 

Ultimately, 80% of patients and potential patients in the Midwest Metropolitan area responded that they would pay a non-zero amount. This response was different from the almost 100% of physician respondents who reported some level of discomfort asking their patients to pay for a product out of pocket. This uncovered a deeper care issue apparent among all providers: insurance reimbursement. Handling the administration around running a clinic as a business has been the number-one issues reported by all caregivers. This frustration covers coding to electronic records. The I-Corps team continues to be greatly influenced by changes in the healthcare insurance industry.

 

The team was fascinated to see an increase in physician awareness and action for handling administrative difficulties related to running their clinics as a business. For example, at the last sports medicine conference, a well-attended conference session was focused on business marketing. There is also an industry increase, focus, and spend on medical practice advertising. Several smaller distributorships and clinics expressed frustration in being able to compete with larger institutions due to the high initial capital necessary to get the market data discussed at annual meetings and in turn using that to launch large-scale marketing efforts. The team hopes to capitalize on the opportunity to bring clinics a product that can help differentiate their practice among competitors.

 

In summary, the team has decided to pursue the medical industry for their novel technology in shape-confirming system for protective irregular shapes. After input from hundreds of stakeholder interviews, the technology is being actualized as a bone brace for fractures and joint pain. Shifts in the healthcare insurance industry and race to capture more patients will directly impact the commercial future of the team’s technology in medicine.
